Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Multilocus phylogenetics and species delimitation using sequence-capture and next-gen sequencing and its application in Adansonia (Malvaceae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
Species are the basic units of taxonomy, playing an important role in scientific communication and environmental policy. While the theoretical understanding of the species concept has advanced greatly, methodologies for the objective delimitation of species remain inefficient. This study by researchers at the University of Wisconsin - Madison and Iowa State University will develop new computational tools to make species delimitation more efficient. Their research will also address a central question in biology: What is a species? This study will use the genus Adansonia (the baobabs) as a testing ground for these methods. Baobabs are iconic trees of great cultural, ecological, and economic importance in Madagascar, continental Africa, and northwestern Australia, and are also a microcosm for many of the challenges that arise in species delimitation. The work will train undergraduate researchers, K-12 teachers, graduate students, and a postdoctoral associate at the interface of taxonomy, genomics, and computational statistics and provide several opportunities to establish international collaboration. Together, this research will provide new insights into Adansonia systematics and provide a new framework to facilitate species delimitation in diverse groups.

Species delimitation encompasses diverse methods that use genetic, morphological and other trait data to guide taxonomic grouping (placing organisms in hierarchically nested taxa) and ranking (deciding where taxa sit relative to the transition from tree-like relationships at higher levels to reticulate genealogies within populations). Species delimitation remains challenging in many groups due to polyploidy, introgression, and/or species with complex geographic patterns of morphological variation. However, opportunities for progress are offered by recent advances in high throughput sequencing technologies that facilitate rapid acquisition of multilocus DNA sequence data, and by new analytical methods for species level taxonomic problems. Using baobabs as a model, this study will develop a rapid and efficient experimental protocol using sequence capture technology and next-generation sequencing that will allow the application of different species delimitation methods. In addition to deploying existing analytical methods, the researchers will extend the Bayesian Phylogenetics and Phylogeography (BPP) method to formally incorporate morphology and geography. Further, they will add capability to the software program BUCKy for identifying cases where the data imply hybridization or introgression that could be applied in diverse groups of organisms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research used baobab trees as a model system for developing improved methods for using genomic analysis to delimit species and detect past gene flow between species. Baobabs are charismatic trees of dry forests in Africa, Madagascar, and Western Australia, which are exploited for economic products (fruit pulp and seed oil) in some areas. Baobabs have traditionally been divided into 8 species, six in Madagascar and one each in Africa and Australia, although just prior to this project a second species was hypothesized to exist in Africa. The relationships between the eight described species distributed across continents have been uncertain. Baobabs have large, nocturnal flowers that are pollinated by either mammals (bats and/or primates) or hawkmoths, but questions still remain as to how many transitions in pollination system there have been in the history of the group.

Theoreticians in the group developed a way to include quantitative morphological data when trying to delimit species using a widely used species delimitation method (BPP). We also developed a statistical test that biologists can use to evaluate whether a set of genomic data are compatible with a history of tree-like species splitting or if, instead, reticulation (gene flow between species lineages) needs to be invoked. As an extension of the latter, we developed a new method and computer program that can be used to reconstruct reticulations from genomic data. This method has now been deployed by many scientists to help them reconstruct reticulate evolution.

Applying these and pre-existing methods to baobab genetic variation we made several significant discoveries. We determined that the supposed second African baobab is not supported by the available data and that there is a rather sharp genetic distinction between the baobabs in West Africa from those in the rest of the continent. We resolved relationships among the Madagascan species but found surprising evidence of ancient gene flow from the African species, which is mammal pollinated, into the ancestor of the two mammal-pollinated species on Madagascar.  This finding raises the possibility that the evolutionary transition from hawkmoth to mammal pollination in Madagascar may have been aided by the acquisition of genes from the African species.  More detailed studies of genetic variation among the Madagascan species suggested (a) northern populations of the widespread species Adansonia za should be recognized as a separate species, A. bozy, and (b) despite flowering at different times of year there has been some gene flow between recognized species. Finally, genomic comparisons between baobabs and close relatives, such as cotton, durian, and chocolate, suggested a complex history of genome instability, including instances of chromosome doubling and perhaps ancient hybridization.

Field experiments on the reproductive biology of the African species suggested some new insights, particularly that baobabs need to receive pollen from a different tree to set fruit, and that very few pollinators in southern Africa move between trees. This is significant because it suggests that farmers seeking to increase fruit yield should manually transfer pollen between flowers on different trees.  Additionally, we found unexpected chemical constituents in the nectar and floral scent of the African baobab.

The project supported the training of more than a dozen undergraduate students and three graduate students in genomic research, statistics, and/or chemical ecology.  Results were presented to professional scientists in multiple peer-reviewed publications (8 publish and four in progress), research talks and workshops on computational methods. During the funding period the investigators also participated in workshops for high school teachers, published a laboratory activity for introductory biology courses, and assisted print and television journalists working on baobab-related stories.
